Definition: When you buy stocks, you own a small part of a company.
Example: Buying stock in a company means you own a piece of that company.

Definition: When you buy bonds, you are lending money to a company or government and they pay you interest.
Example: When you buy a bond, the company or government promises to pay you back with interest.

Definition: These are like baskets that hold different types of investments (stocks, bonds, etc.) so you don't need to pick individual ones.
Example: Instead of buying one stock, you can invest in a mutual fund that holds many stocks.

Definition: This is money a company gives you as a thank you for owning their stock.
Example: If you own stock in a company, they might send you dividends every year.

Definition: The extra money you earn when you lend money or put it in a savings account.
Example: If you put money in the bank, they pay you interest over time.

Definition: Things that are worth money or can be turned into money.
Example: Your car, house, and savings are all examples of assets.

Definition: Money you owe, like debts or loans.
Example: Your credit card debt or a car loan are liabilities.

Definition: This is how much of a company or property you own after subtracting what you owe.
Example: If you own a house, your equity is how much it is worth minus the mortgage.

Definition: When the prices of things go up, meaning your money doesn't buy as much as it used to.
Example: If inflation is high, the same amount of money buys fewer things than before.

Definition: Money or things you own that can be used to make more money.
Example: A business uses capital to buy equipment or pay employees to make more money.

Definition: A mix of investments you own, like stocks, bonds, or property.
Example: A portfolio can include stocks, bonds, and real estate.

Definition: The chance you could lose money or not get the returns you expect.
Example: Investing in the stock market has some risk because prices can go up and down.

Definition: Money you set aside for the future, not spent on everyday things.
Example: Putting money into a savings account is a way to save for the future.

Definition: How quickly you can turn something into cash without losing its value.
Example: Cash is the most liquid asset because you can use it immediately. Stocks are also fairly liquid.

Definition: The ability to borrow money and pay it back later.
Example: Using a credit card lets you borrow money to buy things and pay for them later.

Definition: Money you owe to others that you need to pay back.
Example: A student loan is an example of debt that you pay back over time.

Definition: Money you earn from work or investments.
Example: Your salary from your job is your income.

Definition: Money you spend on things you need or want.
Example: Groceries and rent are examples of monthly expenses.

Definition: The total value of everything you own minus everything you owe.
Example: If you own a house worth $100,000 and have $20,000 in debt, your net worth is $80,000.

Definition: The process of making a plan to manage your money and reach your goals.
Example: Creating a budget and saving for a vacation are part of financial planning.
